prompt: Write a poem about underpass echo in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Use a few invented coinages and a named creature. Avoid copying lines from the original.
poem:
The Underwock

'Twas brillig in the underpass,
And echo-dribbles did still grass,
All frimble were the concrete walls,
And the hollow-throats did pass.

Beware the Underwock, my son!
The screetches that imitate,
The claws that catch, the voice that chants,
The mimic in the dark!

He took his echoblade in hand:
Long time the resonant foe he sought—
So rested he by the concrete wall,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Underwock, with eyes of gleam,
Came whispering through the shadowed place,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The echoblade went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Underwock?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.
label: medium

prompt: Write a poem about morning fog in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep a playful ballad cadence with some rhyme. Add an admonition or preparation and a celebratory return. Use some invented words.
poem:
# The Fogberwocky

"Beware the Fogler, my son!
The jaws that bite, the mist that blinds!
Beware the Murkleth, and shun
The frumious Vapofinds!"

He took his Flimish flashlight in hand;
Long time the misty maze he sought;
So rested he by the Grumble-tuft tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in flinkish thought he stood,
The Fogler, with eyes of gleam,
Came wiffling through the foggy wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The Flimish flashlight went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Fogler?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas brillig, and the slithy toves
Did gyre and gimble in the wabe;
All mimsy were the borogoves,
And the mome raths outgrabe.
label: medium

prompt: Write a poem about déjà vu in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Use a few invented coinages and a named creature. Avoid copying lines from the original.
poem:
The Familiar Phantom

In gloaming hour when time bends back,
And shadows dance in Doublicle light,
Beware the trail where memories crack,
And déjà vu takes flight.

The Familiar Phantom lurks about,
With preseen eyes and twisted grin,
It turns the present inside out,
Then turns it out again.

So grab your Time-Splitting Blade, my lad,
And venture through the Twinstage wood,
Where mem'ries wild and future filed
Are misunderstood.

When through the warped and wrinkled wood,
The Phantom comes with flickering form,
With might and will, your sword stood still,
To weather the strange storm.

With flash and gleam, the blade cuts through
The veil of time that felt so new,
The Phantom gasped and faded fast,
As present moments flew.

"And have you fought the Familiar,
That wraith of time and bending space?"
"Yes, I have slain the déjà dragon,
In this confusing place!"

In gloaming hour when time bends back,
And shadows dance in Doublicle light,
Beware the trail where memories crack,
And déjà vu takes flight.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about desire path in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep a playful ballad cadence with some rhyme. Add an admonition or preparation and a celebratory return. Use some invented words.
poem:
# The Pathwocky

'Twas paving and the slithy walks
Did gyre and gimble in the grass;
All trodden were the borogrounds,
Where planned paths would never pass.

"Beware the Pathwocky, my son!
The tracks that cut, the turf that parts!
Beware the Planners, and shun
The frumious Sidewalk-carts!"

He took his willing feet in hand:
Long time the manxome way he sought—
So rested he by the Signpost tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Pathwocky, with earth of brown,
Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,
Where no designer had been!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The trodden ground went snicker-snap!
He left it worn, and with its trail,
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou walked the Pathwocky? Come to my arms, my pathish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas paving and the slithy walks
Did gyre and gimble in the grass;
All trodden were the borogrounds,
Where planned paths would never pass.
label: medium

prompt: Write a poem about conference room in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Use a few invented coinages and a named creature. Avoid copying lines from the original.
poem:
The Corporate Confabberwoky

It was gibbering in the meeting shed,
Where dry-erase boards all frizzled and fled,
And chairs sat where conference attendees led

"Beware the Meetasnarl, my friend!
The jaws that bite productive time,
The claws that catch attentions end!
Avoid the Pointdragonslide,
And flee from the Agenda Grime!"

He took his laser-wand in hand:
Long minutes the project plan rehearsed —
So stood he where the whiteboard spanned,
Project numbers well dispersed.

And as in executhought he stood,
The Meetasnarl, with eyes of blink,
Came trumbling through the schedule wood,
And shuffled through the presentation link!

Decide! Divide! The strategy applied!
His PowerPoint went snicker-snack!
He won the day, with data array,
And victory brought the project back!

"And have you slain the Meetasnarl?
Join the boardroom celebration joy!
O frabjous coup! Callooh! Callay!"
He chimed with meeting ploy.

It was gibbering in the meeting shed,
Where dry-erase boards all frizzled and fled,
And chairs sat where conference attendees led
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about music room in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep a playful ballad cadence with some rhyme. Add an admonition or preparation and a celebratory return. Use some invented words.
poem:
# The Melodlewock

'Twas brillig in the music room, where Tingletocks did play,
On Brumaloon and Whistlefret, all through the livelong day.
Beware the Melodlewock, my son! The notes that bite, the chords that catch!
Beware the Tempo-twister beast, and shun the frumious Note-nibbler's match!

He took his Tunasaur in hand; long time the Chime-chaser he sought,
Resting by the Tumtum tree, and stood awhile in thought.

As in uffish thought he stood, the Melodlewock, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through theScale-tangle wood, and burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The Tunasaur went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Melodlewock? Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!" He chortled in his joy.

'Twas brillig in the music room, where Harmony did bloom,
The Tingletocks and Brumaloons dispelled the sounds of gloom.

prompt: Write a poem about map in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Use a few invented coinages and a named creature. Avoid copying lines from the original.
poem:
The Mapdweller

'Twas cartled, and the scrawly lines
Did zimple and zagmark in the fold;
All furthled were the mapglyphs,
And the inkwends did unfold.

"Beware the Mapdweller, my dear!
The folds that twist, the scales that bind!
He flitz through charts that disappear,
And leaves the map-mazed mind!"

She took her compass bright and true;
Long time the parchment far she scanned;
She traced beyond the Ziggamew,
And past the Meridian land.

And as she stood in wonderment,
The Mapdweller, with ink-black eyes,
Came scribbling through illustration,
With cartographics in disguise.

North, south! East, west! The measuring lines
With careful steps went north-by-east!
She marked the path in charted signs,
And captured the curvy beast!

"Have you mapped the Mapdweller, child?
Come to the atlas, my brave cartograph!
O mazed-filled day! Hooray! Hooray!"
And drew another path.

'Twas cartled, and the scrawly lines
Did zimple and zagmark in the fold;
All furthled were the mapglyphs,
And the inkwends did unfold.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about stage wings in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Use a few invented coinages and a named creature. Avoid copying lines from the original.
poem:
"The Wingwraith"

Twas stygian dark where the winglets glist
And prop-shifters sway,
Behind the scenes where actors quicken
At break of stage-way.

"Beware the Wingwraith, stage-walkers!
The grip that grabs, the breath that chills!
Beware the Flutterby, and shun
The frumious Stage-thrills!"

The prompter took his script-book bright
And searched the wings so deep:
While chorus waited, hushed from sight,
Their lines they'd try to keep.

And, as in backstage nooks they peered,
The Wingwraith, with eyes aflame,
Came whiffling past the sound-clopped wood,
And murmured stagecraft arcane.

One, two! One, two! The pages turned!
The script-light went snicker-snack!
He read it through, and knew it true,
Then shouted "On the track!"

"And hast thou calmed the Wingwraith?
Come to my arms, my staging crew!
O frabjous night! The show goes right!"
They danced in backstage dew.

Twas stygian dark where the winglets glist
And prop-shifters sway,
Behind the scenes where actors quicken
At break of stage-way.
label: high

poem:
The Grimeclaw

'Twas creeping, and the slithery dark
Did coil and stretch through every path:
All trembly stood the ancient trees,
As shadow mocked its aftermath.

"Beware the Grimeclaw, my son!
The grasp that clutches, the slime that sticks!
Beware the Skitterlume, and shun
The dreadful Oozletrix!"

He took his ghostly sword in hand;
Long time the creepy thing he sought—
So rested by the Whisper stone,
And quietly he thought.

And, as in silence deep he stood,
The Grimeclaw, with arms of shade,
Came oozling through the murkwood,
And gobbled as it wade!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The ghostly blade went slash and slay!
He left it dead, with creeping dread,
Then galumphed away.

"And hast thou slain the Grimeclaw, son?
Come to my arms, my fearless boy!
O wondrous day! Hooray! Hurray!"
He cried in utter joy.

poem:
The Awlward

Beware the Awlward, my son!
The point that prods through ply and pelt!
Beware the Stitch-snipe, and run
From the vorpal Needle-swelt!

He took his Leather-pierce in hand:
Long time the toughest tack he sought—
So rested he by the Work-bench tall,
And pondered as he ought.

And, as in thoughty think he stood,
The Awlward, with edge so keen,
Came wuffling through the woollen warp,
And whistled as it pierced clean!

One, two! One, two! With prick and push
The Leather-pierce went poke-prod-pierce!
He made the hole, and with his goal
He went triumphant, fierce!

"And hast thou mastered the Awlward?
Come to my arms, my crafty boy!
O wondrous day! Heegan! Hooray!"
He cheered with tool-rended joy.

Did zizz and garble through the air:

The frumious Harmonix-spots!"

And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The vorpal blade went snicker-snack!
He left it muted, with its head
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Interferwock?

O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"

poem:
The Umbrellawock

'Twas moisty and the drip-drops fell
Did pitter-patter on the pave;
All splashy were the rain-born wells,
And the gutter-rivers rave.

"Beware the Umbrellawock, my friend!
The ribs that spring, the handle that conceals!
Beware the Drizzlemop, and fend
The soggy Gloop-pan wheels!"

He grasped his zanziferous shade;
Through rain-lashed streets he did roam—
Beside the Puddle-jump's cascade,
And found his dry way home.

And, as in drippy thought he trudged,
The Umbrellawock, with drops of doom,
Came tumbling through the storm-clouds surged,
And rattled with its broom!

Flip, flop! Flip, flop! With twist and pop
The zanziferous shade went whirl-flap-fling!
He caught the rain, and sang again,
And went skippity-skip-spring.

"And have you met the Umbrellawock?
You nimble soul, so quick and bright!
O shower day! Hip-hip! Hooray!"
He danced with pure delight.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about film camera in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Use a few invented coinages and a named creature. Avoid copying lines from the original.
poem:
The Flickerfang

In the darkroom of the tulgy wood,
The Flickerfang clicks and snaps;
Its lensglimmer bright, a mimsy sight,
As the filmwhirl unwraps.

Beware the shutterfraps that snap,
The aperture opening wide;
The Focus-sprite dances in light,
While moments inside abide.

Oh, camera bold with viewfinder keen,
You capture time with beamish hand;
Through chemicals and light between,
You make the moment stand.

The Flickerfang with flash so bright,
Does whirr and click with glee;
It snaps the day and freezes night,
For all eternity.

He turned the dial with uffish might,
And pressed the button down;
The Flickerfang did work aright,
And earned its darkroom crown.
label: medium

# The Melodigrawl

'Twas brillig in the music room, where flimsy notes did quimber,
All frimble were the violin strings, the drums did blunder plim.
One zorchious day, a Serenadink came slithering through the clammer,
With soundulous scales and rickety beats that made the chambers sham.

The flumpets blew their fuzzy snorts, the tubas wobbled wide,
The piccolos piped their piercing peaks, with nothing left to hide.
The Serenadink gyrated round with tweedle-deedle-spree,
And all the metronomes went tick-tock-flock in wild disharmony.

The sheet music fluttered, scattered, turned to smithering smize,
As conductor's baton did wig-wag-wobble before the players' eyes.
O frabjous day! What cacophony! What blustery, bumptious bliss!
This music room of muddled tunes did swirl and hiss and fizz!

poem:
The Glimmerwing's Flight

Twas dimmerdeep in the wingdark shade,
Where flitterstrings did softly braid,
All hushwhisper were the stage-sprites fleet,
And the prop-things moved on silent feet.

The Glimmerwing with wingsAskew,
patrols the dark both old and new,
With eyes that burn like ember-glow,
He guards the stage-wide to and fro.

Young Finn with staff of moonlight bright,
Did enter wingdark deep that night,
He passed the flats of painted wood,
And stood exactly where he should.

When out of velvet shadows black,
The Glimmerwing laid ambush track,
Its claws that grip and wings that whirl,
Did try to make young Finn's mind twirl.

With flash and flare and spinabout,
The staff of light cast shadows out,
The Glimmerwing with startled cry,
Fled wingdark deep into the sky.

“And have you faced the wingdark dread?”
The stage director proudly said,
“O valiant boy! Huzzah! Well done!”
With cheering loud they brought the sun.

Now wingdark holds no terror's sting,
For all the backstagers start to sing,
With Finn to lead them through the night,
The stage is filled with dancing light.

poem:
The Awl's Adventure

Gimbletide in the punctulate wood,
Where twistum vines and spinnetts grew,
The holify groves with awl-sharp points,
All glistening with morning dew.

A Vorpal Awl, so keen and bright,
Was carried by a lad so bold,
Through Grumbledeep and Puncturepass,
A story waiting to unfold.

The dreaded Awlwing, fierce and fast,
With piercing beak and talons keen,
Lurked in the shadows of the Murkwood,
A sight never before seen.

The lad approached with caution vast,
His silver awl held at the ready,
He crept and tiptoed through the brush,
His movements slow and steady.

Suddenly, with whiffling sound,
The Awlwing burst from tangled vines,
Its eyes like flames, its beak so sharp,
The most terrifying of signs!

One stab! Two stab! The awl went true!
Through scale and feather, deep and fast,
The Awlwing gave a final cry,
A mighty triumph at the last.

The lad returned with awl in hand,
The Awlwing's head held high with pride,
His father's joyous welcome met,
"O frabjous day! My son has won!"

Now in the hall, the trophy hangs,
A reminder of that fateful day,
When bravery and Vorpal Awl,
Conquered fears along the way.

poem:
The Foglumph's Fog

Twas fogmorn, and the mist-clad land
Did quiver in the haze:
All shadowy were the sleepy drows,
And dampness filled the days.

"Beware the Foglumph, my guest!
The puff that gallumphs, grey and deep!
Beware the Murk-larks, and rest
Not where the vapors seep!"

They took their mist-lamps bright and true;
Long time the fog-banks they trod—
So waited they by bending birch,
Inside the foggy pod.

And, as in foggy wait they stood,
The Foglumph, with breath of mist,
Came writhing through the gloomy wood,
And whispered as it kissed!

Here, there! Here, there! Through vapour drear
Their lights went glim-shimmer-flash!
It curled away, and shot up straight,
And made a dampened splash.

"And have you seen the Foglumph?
Come tell the tale, my fog-folk band!
O clearing day! Hooray! Hurray!"
They joined each other's hand.

Twas fogmorn, and the mist-clad land
Did quiver in the haze:
All shadowy were the sleepy drows,
And dampness filled the days.

The jaws that drone, the thoughts that drag!

The frumious Spreadsheet-slag!"

He took his vorpal clicker-staff
Long time the meetings maze he sought
So paused he by the coffee-pot,
And in bright thought his plan he caught

And, as in focus deep he stood,
The Presentwocky, with eyes of glass,
Came whiffling through the office wood,
And burbled numbers as they pass

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The vorpal clicker went snicker-snack!
He left it stunned, his rhetoric won,
He went galumphing victor back

"And hast thou slain the Presentwocky?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his bonus-joy!
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about awl in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Use a few invented coinages and a named creature. Avoid copying lines from the original.
poem:
The Awlwacky

'Twas snicker-snack, and the moon did gleam
Above the wibble-wobble wood;
The frumious trees began to dream,
And the grickle-grass stood good.

"Beware the Snicker-snatch, my lad!
His pointed nose, his piercing cry!
Beware the Gricklegrath's sharp stab,
Or you'll be punctured by and by!"

He took his trusty awl in hand;
Through brambly paths he did trek—
So paused he by the Gromble land,
And pondered with a beck.

And as in thoughtful stance he stood,
The Snicker-snatch, with eyes so bright,
Came whispering through the tangled wood,
And glittered in the night!

Left, right! Left, right! And in and out
The piercing awl went flicker-flack!
He stabbed it deep, there was no doubt,
And tripped triumphant back.

"And have you pierced the Snicker-snatch?
Come to my arms, my valiant lad!
O wondrous day! What joyful match!"
He cheered, so wildly glad.

'Twas snicker-snack, and the moon did gleam
Above the wibble-wobble wood;
The frumious trees began to dream,
And the grickle-grass stood good.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about creep in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep a playful ballad cadence with some rhyme. Add an admonition or preparation and a celebratory return. Use some invented words.
poem:
The Creeposaurus

'Twas shimmer light, and squibbly groves
Did whiffle and twurl in the glade:
All flimsy were the chubble heaves,
And the grobble snarks delayed.

"Beware the Creeposaurus, my son!
The claws that snatch, the toes that twitch!
Beware the Grumble-bird, and shun
The frumious Lurk-switch!"

He took his Zorble sword in hand:
Long time the gribble foe he sought—
So rested he by the Crawly tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in gribble thought he stood,
The Creeposaurus, with eyes so dim,
Came slithering through the gloomy wood,
And wriggled as it skimmed!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The Zorble blade went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Creeposaurus?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas shimmer light, and squibbly groves
Did whiffle and twurl in the glade:
All flimsy were the chubble heaves,
And the grobble snarks delayed.

prompt: Write a poem about desire path in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Use a few invented coinages and a named creature. Avoid copying lines from the original.
poem:
The Grumbletrod

'Twas snickerbright, and the slab-sun stones
Did glink and glother all around;
All straight were the pavement zones,
And walkers never strayed from ground.

"Beware the Grumbletrod, my lad!
The trails that weave where none should be!
Beware the Fixed-path, fearsome bad,
And shun the frumious Off-way-see!"

He took his scuffle-stomp boots on;
Long time the grassy path he sought—
So paused he by the Mason's dawn,
And stepped where freedom taught.

And, as in wander-wisdom strode,
The Grumbletrod, with earthy gaze,
Come rustling through the thorny grove,
And blazed the trail amaze!

One, two! One, two! And on and on!
The ground went soft with pad-pad-pat!
He walked it true, both old and new,
And tipped his freedom hat.

"And hast thou found the Grumbletrod's line?
Come to the grass, my pathwise boy!
O wandering day! Huzzah! Hurray!"
He filled with trail-worn joy.
label: high

# The Fogleworth

And shun the frumious Gloomtides!"

He took his Vaporsword in hand;

So rested he by the Tumtum tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

The Fogleworth, with eyes of flame,

The Vaporsword went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Fogleworth?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

prompt: Write a poem about third rail hum in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Use a few invented coinages and a named creature. Avoid copying lines from the original.
poem:
The Lightningvore

'Twas brillig in the tunnel deep,
The tracksnakes did their current keep,
All zimming was the volt-hum dread
Where the Grizzletron in shadows fed.

"Beware the Lightningvore, my son,
The claws that spark, the jaws that hum!
Beware the Track-dragon, and shun
The frumious static-plum!"

The track-snake hissed with metal whine,
Its volt-flecked belly bright and fine,
One whirring leap, it sparked the track
With fritzling sounds and thunder-crack.

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The volt-bars went its zizzing flew,
It left the Grizzletron in a daze,
Stunned by the current-haze.

"And hast thou slain the Lightningvore?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
It chortled in its thunder-joy.
label: medium

prompt: Write a poem about film camera in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep a playful ballad cadence with some rhyme. Add an admonition or preparation and a celebratory return. Use some invented words.
poem:
The Camerawock

'Twas shutter-time, and flickery light
Did frame and focus in the glade.
All lensy were the aperture-sprites,
And the film rolls slowly made.

Beware the Camerawock, my lens!
The jaws that click, the flash that snaps!
Beware the Exposuremox, and shun
The frumious Focusclaps!

He took his lenscap in his hand:
Long time the lightwinder he sought—
So rested he by the shutter-tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Camerawock, with eyes of glass,
Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The lenscap went snicker-snack!
He left it flash, and with its click
He went galumphing back.

And hast thou shot the Camerawock?
Come to my arms, my photoboy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!
He chortled in his joy.
label: high
